saint-stanislaus-papczynski.name: Saint Stanislaus Papczyński
saint-stanislaus-papczynski.history: Saint Stanislaus Papczyński (1631–1701) was a Polish priest who founded the Congregation of Marian Fathers of the Immaculate Conception of the Most Blessed Virgin Mary. He dedicated his life to promoting devotion to the Immaculate Conception, praying for the souls in Purgatory, and serving the poor and uneducated, especially through education and pastoral care.

saint-maria-elizabeth-hesselblad.name: Saint Maria Elizabeth Hesselblad
saint-maria-elizabeth-hesselblad.history: Saint Maria Elizabeth Hesselblad (1870–1957) was a Swedish nurse who converted to Catholicism and founded the Bridgettine Sisters of the Most Holy Savior (also known as the Bridgettines), an order aiming to restore the original Bridgettine monastic life. During World War II, she hid Jewish refugees in her convent in Rome, for which she was posthumously recognized as Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem.

saint-jose-sanchez-del-rio.name: Saint José Sánchez del Río
saint-jose-sanchez-del-rio.history: Saint José Sánchez del Río (1913–1928), affectionately known as 'Joselito,' was a Mexican Cristero who was martyred during the Cristero War at the age of 14. He bravely faced torture and execution rather than renounce his Catholic faith, becoming a powerful symbol of religious freedom and steadfast devotion.

saint-jose-gabriel-del-rosario-brochero.name: Saint José Gabriel del Rosario Brochero
saint-jose-gabriel-del-rosario-brochero.history: Saint José Gabriel del Rosario Brochero (1840–1914) was an Argentine priest, widely known as the 'Gaucho Priest' or 'Curita Brochero.' He dedicated his life to serving the impoverished and isolated communities in the mountains of Córdoba, riding long distances on muleback to bring the sacraments, preach, and establish schools and infrastructure. He contracted leprosy from ministering to the sick.

saint-salomone-leclerq.name: Saint Salomone Leclerq
saint-salomone-leclerq.history: Saint Salomone Leclerq (born Guillaume-Nicolas-Louis Leclerq, 1745–1792) was a French priest and a member of the Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools (De La Salle Brothers). He was martyred during the French Revolution, part of the September Massacres, for refusing to swear an oath against the Church. He is revered as one of the 191 martyrs of Paris.

saint-manuel-gonzalez-garcia.name: Saint Manuel González García
saint-manuel-gonzalez-garcia.history: Saint Manuel González García (1877–1940) was a Spanish bishop and the founder of the Missionaries Eucharistic Nuns of Nazareth and the Missionaries of Saint John Baptist of the Sacred Host. Known as the 'Bishop of the Tabernacle,' he dedicated his life to promoting devotion to the Eucharist, especially the neglected Sacrament, and encouraging a profound love for Jesus in the Blessed Sacrament.

saint-lodovico-pavoni.name: Saint Lodovico Pavoni
saint-lodovico-pavoni.history: Saint Lodovico Pavoni (1784–1849) was an Italian priest and the founder of the Sons of Mary Immaculate (Pavonians). He dedicated his life to the education and vocational training of poor and abandoned boys, especially through technical and professional schools, aiming to provide them with both spiritual and practical formation for life.

saint-alfonso-maria-fusco.name: Saint Alfonso Maria Fusco
saint-alfonso-maria-fusco.history: Saint Alfonso Maria Fusco (1839–1910) was an Italian priest and the founder of the Sisters of Saint John the Baptist (Battistine Sisters). He dedicated his life to caring for and educating poor and abandoned children, establishing orphanages and schools where girls could receive a comprehensive education rooted in Christian values.

saint-elizabeth-of-the-trinity.name: Saint Elizabeth of the Trinity
saint-elizabeth-of-the-trinity.history: Saint Elizabeth of the Trinity (born Élisabeth Catez, 1880–1906) was a French Discalced Carmelite nun. She is known for her profound spirituality focused on the indwelling of the Blessed Trinity within the soul and her 'prayer to the Trinity.' She died young after a prolonged illness, offering her sufferings for the Church and the world.
